question: What does it mean for a time series to be mean reverting?
options: A) The time series tends to fall when its level is above its long-run mean and rise when its level is below its long-run mean.
B) The time series tends to exhibit a constant growth rate.
C) The time series exhibits significant serial correlation.
D) The time series has a unit root.
justification: A time series is mean reverting if it tends to fall when its level is above its long-run mean and rise when its level is below its long-run mean.

question: What is a key limitation of coefficients in time-series models?
options: A) They are often unstable across different sample periods.
B) They do not account for nonstationarity of the time series.
C) They are directly affected by residuals in the model.
D) They are only valid for log-linear trend models.
justification: A key limitation of coefficients in time-series models is that they are often unstable across different sample periods.

question: How can a time series with a unit root be transformed for analysis with an AR model?
options: A) By adding a seasonal lag to the AR model.
B) By calculating the autocorrelations of the residuals.
C) By first-differencing the time series.
D) By using a log-linear trend model.
justification: A time series with a unit root can be transformed for analysis with an AR model by first-differencing the time series.

question: What is an n-period moving average of a time series xt?
options: A) The sum of the current and past (n-1) values of the time series, divided by n.
B) The sum of the next (n+1) values of the time series, divided by n.
C) The sum of the squared residuals of the time series, divided by n.
D) The sum of the lagged values of an AR model, divided by n.
justification: An n-period moving average of a time series xt is calculated as [xt + xt −1 + . . . + xt −( n −1)]/n.

question: What does significant serial correlation of the error term at seasonal lags indicate in a time series?
options: A) The time series has significant seasonality.
B) The time series is covariance stationary.
C) The time series has a unit root.
D) The time series is mean reverting.
justification: If the error term of a time-series model shows significant serial correlation at seasonal lags, it indicates that the time series has significant seasonality.

question: How can an AR model with a seasonal lag be used for forecasting?
options: A) By calculating the first-q autocorrelations of the time series.
B) By adding a term lagged four quarters to an AR(1) model.
C) By first-differencing the time series.
D) By estimating the ARMA model order.
justification: An AR model with a seasonal lag can be used for forecasting by adding a term lagged four quarters to an AR(1) model on quarterly observations.

question: What is autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH) in time-series analysis?
options: A) A model that uses residuals of a time series to predict its current value.
B) A model that accounts for the variability of the error term over time.
C) A test for the presence of unit roots in a time series.
D) A method for correcting seasonality in a time-series model.
justification: Autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH) in time-series analysis refers to a model that accounts for the variability of the error term over time.

question: When can linear regression be used to model the relationship between two time series?
options: A) When both time series have a unit root.
B) When both time series are covariance stationary.
C) When either time series has a unit root.
D) When either time series is mean reverting.
justification: Linear regression can be used to model the relationship between two time series when both time series are covariance stationary.

question: What can be concluded if a time series has a unit root and is cointegrated with another time series?
options: A) Linear regression should not be used to model the relationship.
B) Linear regression can be safely used to model the relationship.
C) The time series is mean reverting.
D) The time series is covariance stationary.
justification: If a time series has a unit root and is cointegrated with another time series, linear regression can be safely used to model the relationship.

question: How can the predicted trend value for a time series be evaluated in a linear trend model?
options: A) By examining the residuals of the model.
B) By calculating the autocorrelations of the time series.
C) By comparing the fitted values to the observed values.
D) By estimating the AR model order.
justification: The predicted trend value for a time series in a linear trend model can be evaluated by comparing the fitted values to the observed values.

question: What condition must a time series satisfy to be considered covariance stationary?
options: A) The expected value must be constant and finite in all periods.
B) The variance must be constant and finite in all periods.
C) The covariance with itself for a fixed number of periods in the past or future must be constant and finite in all periods.
D) All of the above
justification: A time series must satisfy all three conditions of constant and finite expected value, variance, and covariance to be considered covariance stationary.

question: What does it mean if the time series is covariance stationary?
options: A) It will be mean reverting.
B) It follows a log-linear trend.
C) It exhibits significant serial correlation.
D) It has a unit root.
justification: If a time series is covariance stationary, it will be mean reverting.

question: How is the root mean squared error (RMSE) used to compare forecast accuracy of different time-series models?
options: A) A smaller RMSE implies greater forecast accuracy.
B) A larger RMSE implies greater forecast accuracy.
C) The RMSE is not a reliable criterion for comparing forecast accuracy.
D) The RMSE is only applicable for linear trend models.
justification: The root mean squared error (RMSE) is a criterion for comparing forecast accuracy of different time-series models, where a smaller RMSE implies greater forecast accuracy.

question: How can autoregressive time series be distinguished from moving-average time series?
options: A) Autoregressive time series have large and gradually declining autocorrelations, while moving-average time series have sudden drops to zero after the first q autocorrelations.
B) Autoregressive time series have zero autocorrelations at all lags, while moving-average time series have nonzero autocorrelations at all lags.
C) Autoregressive time series have a constant growth rate, while moving-average time series exhibit significant serial correlation.
D) Autoregressive time series have a moving average component, while moving-average time series have an autoregressive component.
justification: Autoregressive time series can be distinguished from moving-average time series by their autocorrelation patterns. question: How is the relative frequency of observations in a bin calculated?
options: A) By dividing the number of observations in the bin by the total number of observations
B) By dividing the total number of observations by the number of observations in the bin
C) By multiplying the number of observations in the bin by the total number of observations
D) By subtracting the number of observations in the bin from the total number of observations
justification: The relative frequency of observations in a bin is calculated by dividing the number of observations in the bin by the total number of observations.

question: How is a frequency polygon different from a histogram?
options: A) A frequency polygon is used for categorical data, while a histogram is used for numerical data
B) A frequency polygon uses lines to connect midpoints of bars in a histogram
C) A frequency polygon displays the cumulative relative frequency, while a histogram does not
D) A frequency polygon is used for one variable, while a histogram can display multiple variables simultaneously
justification: A frequency polygon uses lines to connect successive midpoints of bars representing class frequencies in a histogram.

question: How is a tree-map used in data visualization?
options: A) To organize and label data for analysis
B) To present the correlations between multiple variables
C) To summarize and classify textual data
D) To display categorical data using colored rectangles
justification: A tree-map is a graphical tool used to display categorical data by representing distinct groups with colored rectangles, with the area of each rectangle proportional to the value of the corresponding group.

question: How is a scatter plot matrix different from a regular scatter plot?
options: A) A scatter plot matrix displays scatter plots between pairs of variables
B) A scatter plot matrix visualizes the joint variation of categorical data
C) A scatter plot matrix is used for displaying the frequency distribution of categorical data
D) A scatter plot matrix is used for visualizing the change of data series over time
justification: A scatter plot matrix organizes scatter plots between pairs of variables into a matrix format, allowing inspection of all pairwise relationships between more than two variables in one combined visual.

question: What is the key consideration when selecting among chart types?
options: A) The number of variables to be visualized
B) The complexity of the data analysis required
C) The purpose of visualizing the data
D) The size of the dataset
justification: The key consideration when selecting among chart types is the intended purpose of visualizing the data, whether it is for exploring/presenting distributions or relationships or for making comparisons.

question: How is a population defined?
options: A) All members of a specified group
B) A subset of a population
C) Any descriptive measure of a population
D) A quantity computed from a sample
justification: A population is defined as all members of a specified group that is being studied or analyzed.

question: How is the target downside deviation calculated?
options: A) By taking the square root of the average squared deviations from the target
B) By summing the absolute deviations and dividing by the number of observations
C) By dividing the number of observations in a bin by the total number of observations
D) By computing the average squared deviations from the target using only observations below the target
justification: The target downside deviation is calculated by computing the average squared deviations from the target using only observations below the target, providing a measure of the risk of being below a given target.

question: What issues can arise when evaluating correlation?
options: A) Presence of outliers and spurious correlation
B) Inclusion of extreme values in the dataset
C) Skewness and kurtosis of the distribution
D) Range and median of the dataset
justification: Issues that can arise when evaluating correlation include the presence of outliers, which can distort the relationship, and spurious correlation, which can occur due to unrelated factors influencing both variables.

question: Which measure of central tendency is most appropriate for nominal data?
options: A) Mean
B) Median
C) Mode
D) Variance
justification: The mode is the most appropriate measure of central tendency for nominal data, as it represents the most frequently observed value in the dataset.

question: Which measure of dispersion is scale-free and can be used for direct comparisons?
options: A) Variance
B) Range
C) Mean absolute deviation
D) Coefficient of variation
justification: The coefficient of variation is scale-free because it is the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean, allowing direct comparisons of dispersion across different datasets without being influenced by the units of measurement.

question: What does generalization describe in machine learning?
options: A) The model's explanatory power
B) The model's accuracy on test data
C) The model's fit to the training data
D) The model's ability to predict out-of-sample
justification: Generalization describes the degree to which an ML model retains its explanatory power when predicting out-of-sample.

question: What is the main objective of support vector machine (SVM)?
options: A) To seek the optimal hyperplane
B) To maximize the margin between data points
C) To minimize the misclassification rate
D) All of the above
justification: The main objective of support vector machine (SVM) is to seek the optimal hyperplane and maximize the margin between data points.

question: What is hierarchical clustering used for?
options: A) Building a hierarchy of clusters
B) Reducing statistical variability in data estimation
C) Analyzing high-dimensional data
D) Classifying observations into discrete groups
justification: Hierarchical clustering is used to build a hierarchy of clusters.

question: What is the objective of K-means clustering?
options: A) To minimize the sum of squared distances between observations and cluster centroids
B) To maximize the margin between clusters
C) To classify observations into discrete groups
D) To optimize the performance of a neural network
justification: The objective of K-means clustering is to minimize the sum of squared distances between observations and cluster centroids.

question: Which unsupervised machine learning algorithm partitions observations into non-overlapping clusters?
options: A) Principal components analysis (PCA)
B) K-means clustering
C) Hierarchical clustering
D) Neural networks
justification: K-means clustering is the unsupervised machine learning algorithm that partitions observations into non-overlapping clusters.

question: What is the main objective of agglomerative hierarchical clustering?
options: A) To combine clusters into larger ones
B) To progressively partition clusters into smaller ones
C) To reduce the dimensionality of the dataset
D) To create decision nodes in a decision tree
justification: The main objective of agglomerative hierarchical clustering is to combine clusters into larger ones.

question: How does a random forest classifier generate multiple decision trees?
options: A) By applying a bagging method
B) By reducing the number of available features
C) By transforming the features using PCA
D) By iteratively partitioning the data

question: What advantage do deep neural networks (DNNs) have over standard neural networks?
options: A) They can handle more complex tasks
B) They require fewer hidden layers
C) They have lower computational requirements
